Logo of FIFA

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a7/World_cup_hosts.png/500px-
World_cup_hosts.png)](/wiki/File:World_cup_hosts.png)

[](/wiki/File:World_cup_hosts.png "Enlarge")

Map of FIFA World Cup final hosts, 1930–2018. Dark green: twice; middle green:
once; light green: planned until 2022

Seventeen countries have been **[FIFA World Cup](/wiki/FIFA_World_Cup "FIFA
World Cup") hosts** in the competition's twenty tournaments since the
inaugural World Cup in [1930](/wiki/1930_FIFA_World_Cup "1930 FIFA World
Cup"). The organization at first awarded hosting to countries at meetings of
[FIFA](/wiki/FIFA "FIFA")'s congress. The choice of location was controversial
in the earliest tournaments, given the three-week boat journey between South
America and Europe, the two centers of strength in football at the time.

The decision to hold the first cup in Uruguay, for example, led to only four
European nations competing.[1] The next two World Cups were both held in
Europe. The decision to hold the second of these, the [1938 FIFA World
Cup](/wiki/1938_FIFA_World_Cup "1938 FIFA World Cup"), in France was
controversial, as the South American countries had been led to understand that
the World Cup would rotate between the two continents.

Both [Argentina](/wiki/Argentina_national_football_team "Argentina national
football team") and [Uruguay](/wiki/Uruguay_national_football_team "Uruguay
national football team") thus boycotted the tournament.[2] The first
tournament following [World War II](/wiki/World_War_II "World War II"), held
in Brazil in [1950](/wiki/1950_FIFA_World_Cup "1950 FIFA World Cup"), had
three teams withdraw for either financial problems or disagreements with the
organization.[3]

To avoid any future boycotts or controversy, FIFA began a pattern of
alternation between the Americas and Europe, which continued until the [2002
FIFA World Cup](/wiki/2002_FIFA_World_Cup "2002 FIFA World Cup") in Asia. The
system evolved so that the host country is now chosen in a vote by FIFA's
Congress. This is done under an [exhaustive ballot](/wiki/Exhaustive_ballot
"Exhaustive ballot") system. The decision is currently made roughly seven
years in advance of the tournament, though the hosts for the
[2022](/wiki/2022_FIFA_World_Cup "2022 FIFA World Cup") tournament were chosen
at the same time as those for the [2018 tournament](/wiki/2018_FIFA_World_Cup
"2018 FIFA World Cup").

Only Mexico, Italy, France, Germany (West Germany until shortly after the 1990
World Cup) and Brazil have hosted the event on two occasions. [Mexico
City](/wiki/Mexico_City "Mexico City")'s [Estadio Azteca](/wiki/Estadio_Azteca
"Estadio Azteca") and [Rio de Janeiro](/wiki/Rio_de_Janeiro "Rio de
Janeiro")'s [Maracanã](/wiki/Maracan%C3%A3_\(stadium\) "Maracanã \(stadium\)")
are the only venues ever to have hosted two FIFA World Cup finals. Only the
[2002 FIFA World Cup](/wiki/2002_FIFA_World_Cup "2002 FIFA World Cup") had
more than one host, being split between Japan and South Korea.

Upon the selection of [Canada–Mexico–United States
bid](/wiki/Canada%E2%80%93Mexico%E2%80%93United_States_2026_FIFA_World_Cup_bid
"Canada–Mexico–United States 2026 FIFA World Cup bid") for the [2026 FIFA
World Cup](/wiki/2026_FIFA_World_Cup "2026 FIFA World Cup"), the tournament
will be the first to be hosted by more than two countries. Mexico becomes the
first country to host three men's World Cups and its Estadio Azteca, should it
be selected, will become the first stadium to stage three World Cup
tournaments.

## Results of
hosts[[edit](/w/index.php?title=FIFA_World_Cup_hosts&action=edit&section=2
"Edit section: Results of hosts")]

Except 1934, host nations are granted an automatic spot in the World Cup group
stages. The first host ever to fail to advance past the first round was South
Africa in 2010.

Cup")

**Bids** :

  * ![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8b/Flag_of_Hungary_%281915-1918%2C_1919-1946%29.svg/23px-Flag_of_Hungary_%281915-1918%2C_1919-1946%29.svg.png) Hungary
  * ![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0d/Flag_of_Italy_%281861-1946%29_crowned.svg/23px-Flag_of_Italy_%281861-1946%29_crowned.svg.png) Italy
  * ![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/20/Flag_of_the_Netherlands.svg/23px-Flag_of_the_Netherlands.svg.png) Netherlands
  * ![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7d/Flag_of_Spain_%281785%E2%80%931873%2C_1875%E2%80%931931%29.svg/23px-Flag_of_Spain_%281785%E2%80%931873%2C_1875%E2%80%931931%29.svg.png) Spain
  * ![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/4/4c/Flag_of_Sweden.svg/23px-Flag_of_Sweden.svg.png) Sweden
  * ![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fe/Flag_of_Uruguay.svg/23px-Flag_of_Uruguay.svg.png) Uruguay

Before the [FIFA Congress](/wiki/FIFA_Congress "FIFA Congress") could vote on
the first-ever World Cup host, a series of withdrawals led to the election of
Uruguay. The Netherlands and Hungary withdrew, followed by Sweden withdrawing
in favour of Italy. Then both Italy and Spain withdrew, in favour of the only
remaining candidate, Uruguay. The FIFA Congress met in
[Barcelona](/wiki/Barcelona "Barcelona"), Spain on 18 May 1929 to ratify the
decision, and Uruguay was chosen without a vote.[_[citation
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]

Results:

  1. **![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fe/Flag_of_Uruguay.svg/23px-Flag_of_Uruguay.svg.png) Uruguay**
  2. ~~![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0d/Flag_of_Italy_%281861-1946%29_crowned.svg/23px-Flag_of_Italy_%281861-1946%29_crowned.svg.png) Italy~~ _withdrew_
  3. ~~![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7d/Flag_of_Spain_%281785%E2%80%931873%2C_1875%E2%80%931931%29.svg/23px-Flag_of_Spain_%281785%E2%80%931873%2C_1875%E2%80%931931%29.svg.png) Spain~~ _withdrew_
  4. ~~![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/4/4c/Flag_of_Sweden.svg/23px-Flag_of_Sweden.svg.png) Sweden~~ _withdrew_
  5. ~~![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/20/Flag_of_the_Netherlands.svg/23px-Flag_of_the_Netherlands.svg.png) Netherlands~~ _withdrew_
  6. ~~![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8b/Flag_of_Hungary_%281915-1918%2C_1919-1946%29.svg/23px-Flag_of_Hungary_%281915-1918%2C_1919-1946%29.svg.png) Hungary~~ _withdrew_

Notice that the celebration of the first World Cup coincided with the
centennial anniversary of the [first Constitution of
Uruguay](/wiki/Constitution_of_Uruguay_of_1830 "Constitution of Uruguay of
1830"). For that reason, the main stadium built in Montevideo for the World
Cup was named [Estadio Centenario](/wiki/Estadio_Centenario "Estadio
Centenario").

## 1934 FIFA World

## 1950 and 1954 FIFA World

"Edit section: 1950 and 1954 FIFA World Cups")]

### 1950
bid[[edit](/w/index.php?title=FIFA_World_Cup_hosts&action=edit&section=8 "Edit
section: 1950 bid")]

Bid:

  * ![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/49/Flag_of_Brazil_%281960%E2%80%931968%29.svg/22px-Flag_of_Brazil_%281960%E2%80%931968%29.svg.png) Brazil

Brazil, Argentina, and Germany had officially bid for the 1942 World Cup, but
the Cup was cancelled after the outbreak of World War II. The 1950 World Cup
was originally scheduled for 1949, but the day after Brazil was selected by
the FIFA Congress on 26 July 1946 in [Luxembourg
City](/wiki/Luxembourg_\(city\) "Luxembourg \(city\)"), Luxembourg, the World
Cup was rescheduled for 1950.

Result:

  1. **![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/49/Flag_of_Brazil_%281960%E2%80%931968%29.svg/22px-Flag_of_Brazil_%281960%E2%80%931968%29.svg.png) Brazil**

bid[[edit](/w/index.php?title=FIFA_World_Cup_hosts&action=edit&section=9 "Edit
section: 1954 bid")]

Bid:

  * ![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f3/Flag_of_Switzerland.svg/16px-Flag_of_Switzerland.svg.png) Switzerland

The 1954 World Cup hosting duty was decided on 26 July 1946, the same day that
Brazil was selected for the 1949 World Cup, in Luxembourg City. On 27 July,
the FIFA Congress pushed back the 5th World Cup finals by three years,
deciding it should take place in 1954.

Result:

  1. **![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f3/Flag_of_Switzerland.svg/16px-Flag_of_Switzerland.svg.png) Switzerland**

## 1974, 1978, 1982 FIFA World
Cups[[edit](/w/index.php?title=FIFA_World_Cup_hosts&action=edit&section=14
"Edit section: 1974, 1978, 1982 FIFA World Cups")]

Main articles: [1974 FIFA World Cup](/wiki/1974_FIFA_World_Cup "1974 FIFA
World Cup"), [1978 FIFA World Cup](/wiki/1978_FIFA_World_Cup "1978 FIFA World
Cup"), and [1982 FIFA World Cup](/wiki/1982_FIFA_World_Cup "1982 FIFA World
Cup")

Three hosts for the 1974, 1978, and 1982 World Cups were chosen in
[London](/wiki/London "London"), England on 6 July 1966 by the FIFA Congress.
Spain and West Germany, both facing each other in the running for hosting
duties for the 1974 and 1982 World Cups, agreed to give one another a hosting
job. Germany withdrew from the 1982 bidding process while Spain withdrew from
the 1974 bidding process, essentially guaranteeing each a hosting spot.
Mexico, who had won the 1970 hosting bid over Argentina just two years prior,
agreed to withdraw and let Argentina take the 1978 hosting position.

### 1974
results[[edit](/w/index.php?title=FIFA_World_Cup_hosts&action=edit&section=15
"Edit section: 1974 results")]

  3. ~~![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/0/03/Flag_of_Italy.svg/23px-Flag_of_Italy.svg.png) Italy~~ _withdrew_
  4. ~~![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/20/Flag_of_the_Netherlands.svg/23px-Flag_of_the_Netherlands.svg.png) Netherlands~~ _withdrew_

"Edit section: 1986 FIFA World Cup")]

Bid:

  * ![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/21/Flag_of_Colombia.svg/23px-Flag_of_Colombia.svg.png) Colombia

Host voting, handled by the then-[FIFA Executive Committee](/wiki/FIFA_Council
"FIFA Council") (or _Exco_), met in Stockholm on 9 June 1974 and ratified the
unopposed Colombian bid.

Result:

  1. **![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/21/Flag_of_Colombia.svg/23px-Flag_of_Colombia.svg.png) Colombia**

However, Colombia withdrew after being selected to host the World Cup for
financial problems on 5 November 1982, less than four years before the event
was to start. A call for bids was sent out again, and FIFA received intent
from three nations:

  * ![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/c/cf/Flag_of_Canada.svg/23px-Flag_of_Canada.svg.png) Canada
  * ![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fc/Flag_of_Mexico.svg/23px-Flag_of_Mexico.svg.png) Mexico
  * ![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/a/a4/Flag_of_the_United_States.svg/23px-Flag_of_the_United_States.svg.png) United States

In Zürich on 20 May 1983, Mexico won the bidding unanimously as voted by the
Executive Committee, for the first time in FIFA World Cup bidding history
(except those nations who bid unopposed).

Results:

  1. **![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fc/Flag_of_Mexico.svg/23px-Flag_of_Mexico.svg.png) Mexico** unanimous vote
  2. ![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/a/a4/Flag_of_the_United_States.svg/23px-Flag_of_the_United_States.svg.png) United States 0 votes
  3. ![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/c/cf/Flag_of_Canada.svg/23px-Flag_of_Canada.svg.png) Canada 0 votes

## 2002 FIFA World
Cup[[edit](/w/index.php?title=FIFA_World_Cup_hosts&action=edit&section=22
"Edit section: 2002 FIFA World Cup")]

Main article: [2002 FIFA World Cup](/wiki/2002_FIFA_World_Cup "2002 FIFA World
Cup")

**Bids** :

  * ![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/09/Flag_of_South_Korea.svg/23px-Flag_of_South_Korea.svg.png) South Korea/![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1b/Flag_of_Japan_%281870%E2%80%931999%29.svg/22px-Flag_of_Japan_%281870%E2%80%931999%29.svg.png) Japan
  * ![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fc/Flag_of_Mexico.svg/23px-Flag_of_Mexico.svg.png) Mexico

On 31 May 1996, the hosting selection meeting was held in Zürich for the fifth
straight time. A joint bid was formed between Japan and South Korea, and the
bid was "voted by [acclamation](/wiki/Acclamation "Acclamation")", an oral
vote without ballots. The first joint bid of the World Cup was approved,
edging out Mexico.

Results:

  1. **![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/09/Flag_of_South_Korea.svg/23px-Flag_of_South_Korea.svg.png) South Korea/![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1b/Flag_of_Japan_%281870%E2%80%931999%29.svg/22px-Flag_of_Japan_%281870%E2%80%931999%29.svg.png) Japan** (joint bid, voted by acclamation)
  2. ![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fc/Flag_of_Mexico.svg/23px-Flag_of_Mexico.svg.png) Mexico

The 2002 FIFA World Cup was co-hosted in Asia for the first time by South
Korea and Japan (the final was held in Japan). Initially, the two Asian
countries were competitors in the bidding process. But just before the vote,
they agreed with FIFA to co-host the event. However, the rivalry and distance
between them led to organizational and logistical problems. FIFA has said that
co-hosting is not likely to happen again, and in 2004 officially stated that
its statutes did not allow co-hosting bids.[7]

On 6 July 2000, the host selection meeting was held for the sixth straight
time in Zürich. Brazil withdrew its bid three days before the vote, and the
field was narrowed to four. This was the first selection in which more than
one vote round was required. Three votes were eventually needed. Germany was
at least tied for first in each of the three votes, and ended up defeating
South Africa by only one vote after an abstention (see below).

###
Controversy[[edit](/w/index.php?title=FIFA_World_Cup_hosts&action=edit&section=24
"Edit section: Controversy")]

The controversy over the decision to award the [2006 FIFA World
Cup](/wiki/2006_FIFA_World_Cup "2006 FIFA World Cup") to Germany led to a
further change in practice. The final tally was 12 votes to 11 in favour of
Germany over the contenders South Africa, who had been favorites to win. New
Zealand FIFA member [Charlie Dempsey](/wiki/Charlie_Dempsey "Charlie
Dempsey"), who was instructed to vote for South Africa by the [Oceania
Football Confederation](/wiki/Oceania_Football_Confederation "Oceania Football
Confederation"), abstained from voting at the last minute. If he had voted for
the South African bid, the tally would have been 12–12, giving the decision to
FIFA President [Sepp Blatter](/wiki/Sepp_Blatter "Sepp Blatter"), who, it was
widely believed, would then have voted for South Africa.[8]

Dempsey was among eight members of the Executive Committee to receive a fax by
editors of the German satirical magazine _[Titanic](/wiki/Titanic_\(magazine\)
"Titanic \(magazine\)")_ on Wednesday, the night before the vote, promising a
[cuckoo clock](/wiki/Cuckoo_clock "Cuckoo clock") and [Black Forest
ham](/wiki/Black_Forest_ham "Black Forest ham") in exchange for voting for
Germany. He argued that the pressure from all sides including "an attempt to
bribe" him had become too much for him.[9]

On 4 August 2000, consequently, FIFA decided to rotate the hosting of the
final tournaments between its constituent confederations. This was until
October 2007, during the selection of the host for the [2014 FIFA World
Cup](/wiki/2014_FIFA_World_Cup "2014 FIFA World Cup"), when they announced
that they will no longer continue with their continental rotation policy (see
below).[10][11]

## 2010 FIFA World
Cup[[edit](/w/index.php?title=FIFA_World_Cup_hosts&action=edit&section=25
"Edit section: 2010 FIFA World Cup")]

Main article: [2010 FIFA World Cup](/wiki/2010_FIFA_World_Cup "2010 FIFA World

Further information: [List of 2010 FIFA World Cup

FIFA World Cup controversies")

**Bids** :

  * ![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fe/Flag_of_Egypt.svg/23px-Flag_of_Egypt.svg.png) Egypt
  * ![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2c/Flag_of_Morocco.svg/23px-Flag_of_Morocco.svg.png) Morocco
  * ![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/79/Flag_of_Nigeria.svg/23px-Flag_of_Nigeria.svg.png) Nigeria
  * ![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/af/Flag_of_South_Africa.svg/23px-Flag_of_South_Africa.svg.png) South Africa
  * ![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/ce/Flag_of_Tunisia.svg/23px-Flag_of_Tunisia.svg.png) Tunisia / ![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/04/Flag_of_Libya_%281977%E2%80%932011%29.svg/23px-Flag_of_Libya_%281977%E2%80%932011%29.svg.png) Libya

The first World Cup bidding process under continental rotation (the process of
rotating hosting of the World Cup to each confederation in turn) was the [2010
FIFA World Cup](/wiki/2010_FIFA_World_Cup "2010 FIFA World Cup"),[7] the first
World Cup to be held in Africa. On 7 July 2001, during the [FIFA
Congress](/wiki/FIFA_Congress "FIFA Congress") in [Buenos
Aires](/wiki/Buenos_Aires "Buenos Aires"), a decision was ratified, which was
that the rotation will begin in Africa.[12] On 23 September 2002, FIFA's
Executive Committee confirmed that only African member associations, would be
invited to submit bids to host the 2010 FIFA World Cup.[13]

In January 2003, Nigeria entered the bidding process, but withdrew their bid
in September.[14][15] In March 2003, [Sepp Blatter](/wiki/Sepp_Blatter "Sepp
Blatter") initially said Nigeria's plan to co host the 2010 FIFA World Cup
with four African countries would not work.[16] Nigeria had originally hoped
to bid jointly with [West African](/wiki/West_African "West African")
neighbours Benin, Ghana, and Togo.

After it was confirmed by FIFA that joint bidding would not be allowed in the
future, Libya and Tunisia withdrew both of their bids on 8 May 2004. On 15 May
2004 in Zürich (the seventh consecutive time that a host selection has been
made there), South Africa, after a narrow loss in the 2006 bidding, defeated
perennial candidate Morocco to host, 14 votes to 10. Egypt received no votes.

###
Controversy[[edit](/w/index.php?title=FIFA_World_Cup_hosts&action=edit&section=26
"Edit section: Controversy")]

On 28 May 2015, media covering the [2015 FIFA corruption
case](/wiki/2015_FIFA_corruption_case "2015 FIFA corruption case") reported
that high-ranking officials from the South African bid committee had secured
the right to host the World Cup by paying US$10 million in bribes to then-FIFA
Vice President [Jack Warner](/wiki/Jack_Warner_\(football_executive\) "Jack
Warner \(football executive\)") and to other FIFA Executive Committee
members.[17]

On 4 June 2015, FIFA executive [Chuck Blazer](/wiki/Chuck_Blazer "Chuck
Blazer"), having co-operated with the [FBI](/wiki/FBI "FBI") and the Swiss
authorities, confirmed that he and the other members of FIFA's executive
committee were bribed in order to promote the South African 1998 and 2010
World Cups. Blazer stated, "I and others on the FIFA executive committee
agreed to accept bribes in conjunction with the selection of South Africa as
the host nation for the 2010 World Cup."[18][19]

On 6 June 2015, _[The Daily Telegraph](/wiki/The_Daily_Telegraph "The Daily
Telegraph")_ reported that Morocco had received the most votes, but South
Africa was awarded the tournament instead.[20]

"2014 FIFA World Cup")

**Bids** :

  * ![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1a/Flag_of_Argentina.svg/23px-Flag_of_Argentina.svg.png) Argentina
  * ![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/0/05/Flag_of_Brazil.svg/22px-Flag_of_Brazil.svg.png) Brazil
  * ![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/21/Flag_of_Colombia.svg/23px-Flag_of_Colombia.svg.png) Colombia

FIFA continued its continental rotation procedure by earmarking the 2014 World
Cup for South America. FIFA initially indicated that it might back out of the
rotation concept,[21] but later decided to continue it through the 2014 host
decision, after which it was dropped.

Colombia had expressed interest in hosting the 2014 World Cup,[22] but
withdrew undertaking the [2011 FIFA U-20 World
Cup](/wiki/2011_FIFA_U-20_World_Cup "2011 FIFA U-20 World Cup").[23] Brazil
also expressed interest in hosting the World Cup. [CONMEBOL](/wiki/CONMEBOL
"CONMEBOL"), the South American Football Federation, indicated their
preference for Brazil as a host.[24] Brazil was the only nation to submit a
formal bid when the official bidding procedure for CONMEBOL member
associations was opened in December 2006, as by that time, Colombia, Chile and
Argentina had already withdrawn, and Venezuela was not allowed to bid.

Brazil made the first unopposed bid since the initial selection of the [1986
FIFA World Cup](/wiki/1986_FIFA_World_Cup "1986 FIFA World Cup") (when
Colombia was selected as host, but later withdrew for financial problems). The
FIFA Executive Committee confirmed it as the host country on 30 October 2007
by a unanimous decision.[25]

FIFA announced on 29 October 2007 that it will no longer continue with its
continental rotation policy, implemented after the 2006 World Cup host
selection. The newest host selection policy is that any country may bid for a
World Cup, provided that their continental confederation has not hosted either
of the past two World Cups. For the [2018 World Cup bidding
process](/wiki/2018_and_2022_FIFA_World_Cup_bids "2018 and 2022 FIFA World Cup
bids"), this meant that bids from Africa and South America were not allowed.

For the [2022 World Cup bidding
process](/wiki/2018_and_2022_FIFA_World_Cup_bids "2018 and 2022 FIFA World Cup
bids"), this meant that bids from South America and Europe were not
allowed.[26][27] Also, FIFA formally allowed joint bids once more (after they
were banned in 2002), because there was only one organizing committee per
joint bid, unlike Korea–Japan, which had two different organizing
committees.[28] Countries that announced their interest included Australia,
England, Indonesia, Japan, Qatar, Russia, South Korea, United States, the
joint bid of Spain and Portugal and the joint bid of Belgium and
Netherlands.[26][29][30]

The hosts for both World Cups were announced by the FIFA Executive Committee
on 2 December 2010. Russia was selected to host the 2018 FIFA World Cup,
making it the first time that the World Cup will be hosted in Eastern Europe
and making it the biggest country geographically to host the World Cup. Qatar
was selected to host the 2022 FIFA World Cup, making it the first time a World
Cup will be held in the Arab World and the second time in Asia since the 2002
tournament in South Korea and Japan. Also, the decision made it the smallest
country geographically to host the World Cup.[31]

  * ![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2c/Flag_of_Morocco.svg/23px-Flag_of_Morocco.svg.png) Morocco

Under FIFA rules as of 2016, the 2026 Cup could not be in either Europe
([UEFA](/wiki/UEFA "UEFA")) or Asia ([AFC](/wiki/Asian_Football_Confederation
"Asian Football Confederation")),[32][33] leaving an African
([CAF](/wiki/Confederation_of_African_Football "Confederation of African
Football")) bid, a North American ([CONCACAF](/wiki/CONCACAF "CONCACAF")) bid,
a South American ([CONMEBOL](/wiki/CONMEBOL "CONMEBOL")) bid or an Oceanian
([OFC](/wiki/Oceania_Football_Confederation "Oceania Football Confederation"))
bid as other possible options.[34] In March 2017, FIFA's president [Gianni
Infantino](/wiki/Gianni_Infantino "Gianni Infantino") confirmed that "Europe
([UEFA](/wiki/UEFA "UEFA")) and Asia ([AFC](/wiki/Asian_Football_Confederation
"Asian Football Confederation")) had been excluded from the bidding following
the selection of [Russia](/wiki/2018_FIFA_World_Cup "2018 FIFA World Cup") and
[Qatar](/wiki/2022_FIFA_World_Cup "2022 FIFA World Cup") in 2018 and 2022
respectively."[35]

The bidding process was originally scheduled to start in 2015, with the
appointment of hosts scheduled for the FIFA Congress on 10 May 2017 in [Kuala
Lumpur](/wiki/Kuala_Lumpur "Kuala Lumpur"), Malaysia.[36][37] On 10 June 2015,
FIFA announced that the bid process for the 2026 FIFA World Cup was
postponed.[38][39] However, following the [FIFA Council](/wiki/FIFA_Council
"FIFA Council") meeting on 10 May 2016, a new bid schedule was announced for
May 2020 as the last in a four-phase process.[40]

On 14 October 2016, FIFA said it would accept a tournament-sharing bid by
CONCACAF members Canada, Mexico and the United States.[41]

On 10 April 2017, Canada, the United States, and Mexico announced their
intention to submit a joint bid to co-host, with three-quarters of the games
to be played in the U.S., including the final.[42]

On 11 August 2017, Morocco officially announced a bid to host.[43]

Therefore, the official 2026 FIFA World Cup bids were from two football
confederations. The first one was from [CONCACAF](/wiki/CONCACAF "CONCACAF"),
which was [triple bid by Canada, United States and
Mexico](/wiki/Canada%E2%80%93United_States%E2%80%93Mexico_2026_FIFA_World_Cup_bid
"Canada–United States–Mexico 2026 FIFA World Cup bid"),[41][44][45][46] and
the second one was from [CAF](/wiki/Confederation_of_African_Football
"Confederation of African Football") with a [bid by
Morocco](/wiki/Morocco_2026_FIFA_World_Cup_bid "Morocco 2026 FIFA World Cup
bid").[47][48]

The host was announced on 13 June 2018 at the 68th [FIFA
Congress](/wiki/FIFA_Congress "FIFA Congress") in [Moscow](/wiki/Moscow
"Moscow"), Russia.[49] The United Bid from Canada, Mexico and the United
States was selected over the Morocco bid by 134 votes to 65 with 1 selecting
neither and 3 abstentions. This will be the first World Cup to be hosted by
more than two countries. Mexico becomes the first country to host three men's
World Cups and its Estadio Azteca, should selected, will become the first
stadium to stage three World Cup tournaments. On the other hand, Canada
becomes the fifth country to host both the men's and [women's World
Cups](/wiki/FIFA_Women%27s_World_Cup "FIFA Women's World Cup"), after Sweden
(Men's: 1958/Women's: 1995), United States (Men's: 1994/Women's: 1999, 2003),
Germany (Men's: 1974, 2006/Women's: 2011), and France (Men's: 1934,
1998/Women's: 2019). The United States becomes the first country to host both
men's and women's World Cup twice each.

## 2030 FIFA World
Cup[[edit](/w/index.php?title=FIFA_World_Cup_hosts&action=edit&section=30
"Edit section: 2030 FIFA World Cup")]

Main article: [2030 FIFA World Cup](/wiki/2030_FIFA_World_Cup "2030 FIFA World
Cup")

Two early bids for the 2030 FIFA World Cup - the Centennial World Cup - have
been proposed. The first bid has been proposed as a collective bid by the
members of the [Argentine Football
Association](/wiki/Argentine_Football_Association "Argentine Football
Association") and [Uruguayan Football
Association](/wiki/Uruguayan_Football_Association "Uruguayan Football
Association") into a proposed [joint bid from Uruguay and
Argentina](/wiki/Uruguay%E2%80%93Argentina_2030_FIFA_World_Cup_bid
"Uruguay–Argentina 2030 FIFA World Cup bid").[50] The second bid has been a
proposed bid by [The Football Association](/wiki/The_Football_Association "The
Football Association") of England.[51] Under FIFA rules as of 2017, the 2030
World Cup cannot be held in Asia ([AFC](/wiki/Asian_Football_Confederation
"Asian Football Confederation")) because the Asian Football Confederation is
excluded from the bidding following the selection of
[Qatar](/wiki/2022_FIFA_World_Cup "2022 FIFA World Cup") in 2022.[35][51] Also
in June 2017, [UEFA](/wiki/UEFA "UEFA")'s president [Aleksander
Čeferin](/wiki/Aleksander_%C4%8Ceferin "Aleksander Čeferin") stated that
Europe (UEFA) will definitely fight for its right to host the 2030 World
Cup.[52]

The Uruguay–Argentina bid would coincide with the centennial anniversary of
the [first FIFA World Cup final](/wiki/1930_FIFA_World_Cup_Final "1930 FIFA
World Cup Final"), and the bicentennial of the [first Constitution of
Uruguay](/wiki/Constitution_of_Uruguay_of_1830 "Constitution of Uruguay of
1830"). The Uruguay-Argentina bid was officially confirmed on 29 July 2017. A
joint bid was announced by the [Argentine Football
Association](/wiki/Argentine_Football_Association "Argentine Football
Association") and the [Uruguayan Football
Association](/wiki/Uruguayan_Football_Association "Uruguayan Football
Association") on 29 July 2017.[53] Before
[Uruguay](/wiki/Uruguay_national_football_team "Uruguay national football
team") and [Argentina](/wiki/Argentina_national_football_team "Argentina
national football team") played out a goalless draw in Montevideo, [FC
Barcelona](/wiki/FC_Barcelona "FC Barcelona") players [Luis
Suárez](/wiki/Luis_Su%C3%A1rez "Luis Suárez") and [Lionel
Messi](/wiki/Lionel_Messi "Lionel Messi") promoted the bid with commemorative
shirts.[54] On 31 August 2017, it was suggested Paraguay would join as a third
host.[55] CONMEBOL, the South American confederation, confirmed the joint
three-way bid in September 2017.[56]

[English FA](/wiki/The_Football_Association "The Football Association") vice
chairman [David Gill](/wiki/David_Gill_\(executive\) "David Gill
\(executive\)") has proposed that his country could bid for 2030, provided the
bidding process is made more transparent.[57] "England is one of few countries
that could stage even a 48-nation event in its entirety, while Football
Association chief executive Martin Glenn made it clear earlier this year
bidding for 2030 was an option."[51] In June 2017, UEFA stated that "it would
support a pan-British bid for 2030 or even a single bid from England."[58]
Moreover, a possible English bid for 2030 was also backed by the [German
Football Association](/wiki/German_Football_Association "German Football
Association").[59]

On 17 June 2018, the [Royal Moroccan Football
Federation](/wiki/Royal_Moroccan_Football_Federation "Royal Moroccan Football
Federation") announced its co-bidding for the 2030 World Cup. There are two
possible joint bids one with the [Tunisia](/wiki/Tunisian_Football_Federation
"Tunisian Football Federation") and the
[Algeria](/wiki/Algerian_Football_Federation "Algerian Football Federation")
or the other with two UEFA members
[Spain](/wiki/Royal_Spanish_Football_Federation "Royal Spanish Football
Federation") and [Portugal](/wiki/Portuguese_Football_Federation "Portuguese
Football Federation").[60][61]

On 17 June 2018, the [English Football
Association](/wiki/The_Football_Association "The Football Association")
announced that they are in talks with home nations over a UK-wide bid to host
2030 World Cup.[62]

On 10 July 2018, Egypt's Sports Minister expressed interest in bidding to
host.[63]

## 2034 FIFA World
Cup[[edit](/w/index.php?title=FIFA_World_Cup_hosts&action=edit&section=31
"Edit section: 2034 FIFA World Cup")]

Main article: [2034 FIFA World Cup](/wiki/2034_FIFA_World_Cup "2034 FIFA World
Cup")

The first bid for the 2034 FIFA World Cup has been proposed as a collective
bid by the members of the [Association of Southeast Asian
Nations](/wiki/Association_of_Southeast_Asian_Nations "Association of
Southeast Asian Nations"). The idea of a combined ASEAN bid had been mooted as
early as January 2011, when the [Football Association of
Singapore](/wiki/Football_Association_of_Singapore "Football Association of
Singapore")'s then-President, [Zainudin Nordin](/wiki/Zainudin_Nordin
"Zainudin Nordin"), said in a statement that the proposal had been made at an
ASEAN Foreign Ministers meeting.[71] In 2013, Nordin and [Special
Olympics](/wiki/Special_Olympics "Special Olympics") Malaysia President, Datuk
Mohamed Feisol Hassan, recalled the idea for ASEAN to jointly host a World
Cup. Under FIFA rules as of 2017, the 2030 World Cup cannot be held in Asia
([AFC](/wiki/Asian_Football_Confederation "Asian Football Confederation")) as
Asian Football Confederation members are excluded from the bidding following
the selection of [Qatar](/wiki/2022_FIFA_World_Cup "2022 FIFA World Cup") in
2022.[35][51] Therefore, the earliest bid by an AFC member could be made for
2034.[72][73][74][75][76]

Later, Malaysia has withdrawn from involvement but Singapore and other ASEAN
countries continued the campaign to submit a joint bid for the World Cup in
2034. In February 2017, [ASEAN](/wiki/ASEAN "ASEAN") held talks on launching a
joint bid during a visit by FIFA chief [Gianni
Infantino](/wiki/Gianni_Infantino "Gianni Infantino") to Yangon, Myanmar.[77]

In July 2017, Joko Driyono, the Vice-President of Indonesia's Football
Association, during the meeting in Vietnam said that Indonesia and Thailand
were set to lead a consortium of South-East Asian nations in the bid. Driyono
added that, for geographic and infrastructure considerations and the expanded
format (48 teams), at least two or three ASEAN countries combined would be in
a position necessary to host matches.[78][76]

In September 2017, the [Football Association of
Thailand](/wiki/Football_Association_of_Thailand "Football Association of
Thailand")'s Deputy CEO, Benjamin Tan, at the [ASEAN Football
Federation](/wiki/ASEAN_Football_Federation "ASEAN Football Federation") (AFF)
Council meeting, confirmed that his Association has "put in their interest to
bid and co-host" the 2034 World Cup with Indonesia.[76][71] On the same
occasion, the General Secretary of the AFF, Dato Sri Azzuddin Ahmad, confirmed
that Indonesia and Thailand will submit a joint bid.[74][75]

Indonesia is the only Southeast Asian country to have participated in the
World Cup;[79] its national team was the first from Asia to do so and it
became one of the fewest World Cup teams to qualify without playing a match
because of opponents' withdrawals.[80] The [1938 World
Cup](/wiki/1938_FIFA_World_Cup "1938 FIFA World Cup") is the Indonesians' only
appearance to date when they were known as the [Dutch East
Indies](/wiki/Dutch_East_Indies "Dutch East Indies"). A loss to Hungary made
Indonesia the only national team in World Cup history to have played a single
match.[80] Far from ever hosting the World Cup, no other Southeast Asian
country has ever played at the tournament. As of June 2018, Indonesia is
ranked by FIFA at 164th place.[81]

China has announced its interest in bidding several times and reports stated
"that China is likely to host the World Cup for the first time in 2034."[82]

Egypt is considering the possibility of bidding to host the 2034 FIFA World
Cup the country’s Sports and Youth Minister Ashraf Sobhy said on Tuesday.[83]

## Host country
performances[[edit](/w/index.php?title=FIFA_World_Cup_hosts&action=edit&section=33
"Edit section: Host country performances")]

Further information: [National team appearances in the FIFA World
Cup](/wiki/National_team_appearances_in_the_FIFA_World_Cup "National team
appearances in the FIFA World Cup")

It is widely considered that [home advantage](/wiki/Home_advantage "Home
advantage") is common in the World Cup, with the host team usually performing
above average.[86] Of the eight countries that have won the tournament, only
Brazil and Spain have not been champions while hosting, and England has their
only title as hosts.

Further, Sweden got to its only final as hosts of the 1958 tournament, and
only the Swedes and Brazilians finished as runner-up in home soil.[87] The
host country reached the semi-finals thirteen times in twenty tournaments, and
both Chile and South Korea had their only finishes on the top four at home.
Only South Africa in 2010 managed to not go past the group stage.[88]
